Then you should read his statements more carefully. It says 'by their fruit shall you know THEM.' (The people being judged.) Not the religion itself.

 
 This is one of the amusing things about "Christianity" that I find to be oh-so-convenient for Christians to revel in.
 
 The technique to ignore when "Christianity" gives a negative result and to claim it's not really "Christian", but to endorse the positive as uniquely and exclusively "Christian". (i.e. the positive thing was CAUSED by Christianity, ignoring other non-Christian elements where the same thing is observed)
 
 I realize that the CHRISTIAN phrase is to *judge christians by their fruit*, but a much more REAL methodology is to judge the whole by its ACTUAL effect instead of picking and choosing what we want to claim as part of the group.
 
 Just imagine if gays had that sort of privilege. We could declare that people who contract HIV or do drugs aren't really "gay". Political parties could quickly and efficiently distance themselves from anybody caught in a scandal by renouncing or distancing their association in that party.
 
 The real standard is to judge the whole by the effects brought about by the whole.
 Getting to pick and choose which consequences you want to claim, picking only the positive ones, is a fairy tale of propaganda.
 
 
 
I'm sure that approach is convenient when you want to attack the religion and need an excuse.

 What ridiculous absurdity!
 
 Suppose we had a process by which a corporation processed fruit for canning.
 And then every 3rd can that came out of the production line was rotten.
 
 Would it be rational for the CEO to say "Well, that's just an example of where the product didn't live up to the process"???
 The CEO gets to say "Well, that can wasn't really Del Monte..."
 Of course not!
 
 The fact that the processing allows for such corruption should be taken into account when judging the process.
 Allowing people to just pick and choose what products they want to claim as products of the process is ridiculous.
 That standard works NOWHERE.
 
 If anything, you figure out where the process went wrong.
 But that can't happen with Christianity, cause it requires Christians assume that Christianity is flawless as a fundamental ideal.
 
 Taking into account ALL the fruits of christianity is not a process adopted to "attack" the religion.
 It's just a common sense practice that christianity tries to weasel out of, that should be applied universally.
 
 And to head off the misinterpretation that I sense coming, the distinction is NOT that there are never exclusions which should not be used to judge the theology. Some examples of exclusions exist.
 The point is that the policy of rejecting ALL bad fruit as non-christian is nonsensical.

 One problem with this argument is that not all Christians agree with what "Christian" standards of behavior should be. Some Christians insist that, even though Jesus never said anything about being gay or about gay people, that he nevertheless "condemned" homosexuality through other people's writings in the Bible. Other Christians dispute this claim and note that Jesus never said anything about "homosexuality," and therefore, Christians should not presume that God condemns it. They look to other quotations attributed to Jesus in the Bible, such as "judge not lest ye be judged," and "love your neighbor as yourself." Some Christians accept divorce, even though Jesus reportedly called for no divorce, while other Christians insist there can be no divorce, even as they permit couples to anul their marriages. Some Christians support going to war, while other Christians insist that Jesus meant "turn the other cheek" and that all war is contrary to God's will. Some Christians support the death penalty, while other Christians insist that Jesus opposed all killing. 
 
 There have been groups acting in the name of Jesus and Christianity who have done things that most of us would regard as clearly immoral. The Ku Klux Klan is one such group. Christians who supported white supremacy, racial segregation, and before that slavery asserted that they were acting in the name of Jesus. These were not just individuals, but whole churches. The Southern Baptists came into existence as the pro-slavery wing of Baptists. 
 
 To say that Christians agree on what the Christian behavior ought to be, and that individuals simply fall short of acting as Christians, is to ignore the many passionate disagreements and even battles among different groups of Christians over what Christian behavior ought to be. Christians have never all agreed on what Christian behavior should be. Different groups of Christians have interpreted Jesus' message, and the message of the Gospels, differently.

 Well, I do think the core teachings of Christianity are good. I guess the real question is whether or not a religion is defined solely by the behavior of its adherents, or solely by its central teachings (from it's founder), or some combination of the two. I tend to associate Christianity with Christ, so I tend to think of it in terms of it's core teachings and whether or not it's adherents live up to it. It's sort of like the old question of whether you view a political party by it's members or by it's platform. Sometimes the two are not in sync. 
 
 I think there are parts of the Bible there is not consensus on, but I do think there are central tenets that most or all Christians agree on, that are the very core of the religion.
Ohioprof

I think there are parts of the Bible there is not consensus on, but I do think there are central tenets that most or all Christians agree on, that are the very core of the religion.

 
 That may be true, but as in arguments about the meaning of the constitution or the Declaration of Independence, different people view the meaning of the core tenets differently. For example, when it comes to turning the other cheek and loving one's enemies, I think different Christians look very differently upon what this means in practice. Some interpret the teachings of Jesus to mean that we should never kill another person or go to war. Others say there are exceptions to the teachings of Jesus, or circumstances where people should apply different standards. Some Christians regard divorce as completely unacceptable because of the teachings of Jesus, while other Christians, perhaps most, do accept divorce, and many even get divorced themselves. When it comes to how to regard gay people, Christians are also divided, particularly because Jesus never said anything about this topic. I certainly do not think that opposing equality for gay people can be a central tenet of Christianity, given this absence of any statement at all on the subject by Jesus, and it seems that some Christians have to really stretch their interpretations of the teachings of Jesus in order to claim that gay people are condemned or should be excluded from the church. 
 
 It seems to me that there is more disagreement than agreement among Christians about what some of the core tenets of the faith mean in practice. And it seems that, while people do indeed fall short of their ideal in practicing their faith, there are also many Christians who have a different understanding of what their faith calls for than other Christians do. For example, many Christians insist that gay people have fallen short of the standards of Jesus and engage in sin by loving their spouses. Most gay Christians, at least the gay Christians I know, disagree with this and say that in their understanding of Christian tenets, being gay and loving one's spouse are not sins at all. Therefore, they have not fallen short, but instead have a different understanding of what the tenets of the faith call for.

lesz

I do think there are central tenets that most or all Christians agree on, that are the very core of the religion.

 
 Tolerance of dissent from Christianity is a value at the core of Christianity more honoured in its breach than its observance. But at least intolerance is something the majority of Christians agree on, including intolerance of Christians belonging to different traditions.
jyoshu

That may be true, but as in arguments about the meaning of the constitution or the Declaration of Independence, different people view the meaning of the core tenets differently. For example, when it comes to turning the other cheek and loving one's enemies, I think different Christians look very differently upon what this means in practice. Some interpret the teachings of Jesus to mean that we should never kill another person or go to war.

 
 That's true, but I'd say at this point you're getting into matters of application as opposed to consensus on what Jesus taught. People are still going to say he taught to turn the other cheek, and at least there's going to be consensus on the idea of that on the most basic level--i.e. in our relationships and the way we deal with each other in an 'everyday' way. In other words, if you ask pretty much any Christian "should you live by the ideal of turning the other cheek", they're probably going to say yes. You may only find consensus in the fact that they believe there is importance in the ideal, if only on an interpersonal level, nevertheless I think it will still be consensus.
 
 
For example, many Christians insist that gay people have fallen short of the standards of Jesus and engage in sin by loving their spouses. Most gay Christians, at least the gay Christians I know, disagree with this and say that in their understanding of Christian tenets, being gay and loving one's spouse are not sins at all. Therefore, they have not fallen short, but instead have a different understanding of what the tenets of the faith call for.

 
 Well again, I'm talking about central tenets here, and the issue of gay relationships being immoral or not or gay people is not a central tenet. And I don't think it is for most Christians. I think the basic teachings about forgiveness and compassion, along with some central doctrinal issues agreed upon by the early church are the central tenets of Christianity. And I think these are mostly universal in terms of most Christians. From my experience, the issue of gay relations is not one of those, and really is not that high up on the list in terms of importance for most Christians. They may, somewhere along the way, have concerns about it, but I dare say that most have not gone out of their way to take a stand yea or nea on it and done Biblical studies on it. I think it sometimes SEEMS that it's a huge issue among Christians because a minority (in the religion) of leaders called the religious right has made it a very vocal and outspoken priority for some reason.
Ohioprof

That's true, but I'd say at this point you're getting into matters of application as opposed to consensus on what Jesus taught. People are still going to say he taught to turn the other cheek, and at least there's going to be consensus on the idea of that on the most basic level--i.e. in our relationships and the way we deal with each other in an 'everyday' way. In other words, if you ask pretty much any Christian "should you live by the ideal of turning the other cheek", they're probably going to say yes. You may only find consensus in the fact that they believe there is importance in the ideal, if only on an interpersonal level, nevertheless I think it will still be consensus.
 
 
 
 Well again, I'm talking about central tenets here, and the issue of gay relationships being immoral or not or gay people is not a central tenet. And I don't think it is for most Christians. I think the basic teachings about forgiveness and compassion, along with some central doctrinal issues agreed upon by the early church are the central tenets of Christianity. And I think these are mostly universal in terms of most Christians. From my experience, the issue of gay relations is not one of those, and really is not that high up on the list in terms of importance for most Christians. They may, somewhere along the way, have concerns about it, but I dare say that most have not gone out of their way to take a stand yea or nea on it and done Biblical studies on it. I think it sometimes SEEMS that it's a huge issue among Christians because a minority (in the religion) of leaders called the religious right has made it a very vocal and outspoken priority for some reason.

 
 I agree with your major points in this post, which is amazing indeed! We often disagree, but we apparently agree on this. 
 
 Of course, with the evidence from the Gospels found at Nag Hammadi, the Gnostic Gospels, the question of what Jesus said has been thrown wide open. But that's for another discussion.
